## Disclosure
Full disclosure: I have not yet sailed Adventure of the Seas. Until I do, this Logbook is an aggregate of vetted guest soundings, taken in their own wake, trimmed and edited to our standards.

## Intro
Fifty years after standing watch in a very different ocean, I boarded *Adventure of the Seas* from Port Canaveral in **April 2024** with my daughter, son-in-law, and two grandkids. She’s no destroyer—she’s a memory-maker.

## The Crew and Staff
From the gangway, crew moved my grandson’s wheelchair like it was precious cargo. A steward tucked a note under our door: “Welcome aboard, Captain.” My chest swelled like it used to at colors.

## Embarkation & Disembarkation
Royal’s app made check-in painless; we were on the Promenade before my coffee cooled. Leaving in **April 2024** hurt more than my knees ever did.

## The Real Talk
She's seasoned—some trim shows her years, and Wi-Fi napped mid-Gulf—but smaller ships make faster friends. The [Schooner Bar](/restaurants/schooner-bar.html) became our family's living room. Before sailing, I ran the math on drinks—that [calculator](/drink-calculator.html) saved us more than the package would've.

## Tear-Jerker
At sunset, my granddaughter slipped her hand into mine: “Grandpa, now I understand why you talk about the sea.” The wake behind us looked like a stitched-up timeline.

## Closing Thoughts
I came to show them my ocean. The ship showed me my family instead.

*(Sailing window: Western Caribbean — Perfect Day at CocoCay, Cozumel, Costa Maya | **April 2024**)*

## Disclosure

## Intro
I hadn’t painted anything but gray since my husband died. In **June 2024**, I booked a **5-night** sailing to practice joy in small strokes.

## The Crew and Staff
My waiter learned I preferred tea over wine. Luz, a steward, said she sketches when she misses home. “We both find God in the horizon,” she told me. I wrote it in my sketchbook.

## Embarkation & Disembarkation
Boarding felt like opening a fresh canvas; disembarkation felt like signing the corner—work not finished, simply paused.

## The Real Talk
Elevators creaked like old galleries, and the Wi-Fi wasn’t gallery-grade either—but sunsets graded on a kinder curve.

## Tear-Jerker
On night three I painted the exact color of my husband’s favorite tie from memory—then realized I was smiling while I worked.

## Closing Thoughts
I didn’t escape grief; I invited light to sit beside it.

*(Sailing window: Western Caribbean — Cozumel, Costa Maya | **June 2024**)*

## Intro
By **March 2025** I was ready to breathe again. We chose a **7-night** Western Caribbean run so my son could have new friends and I could have new quiet.

## The Crew and Staff
The Adventure Ocean team memorized his allergy list and his favorite joke by day two. Our steward left towel animals holding paper hearts labeled “First Mate.”

## Embarkation & Disembarkation
A porter said, “Mama, you’re already on vacation.” He was right. Disembarkation came too fast; my son cried because goodbyes are hard at nine.

## The Real Talk
Budget cabin was cozy; Wi-Fi blinked near Cozumel. But the ship never blinked on kindness.

## Tear-Jerker
On the last night he whispered, “Mom, I think Dad can hear the ocean from heaven.” I held him while the wake glittered like a runway.

## Closing Thoughts
We didn’t fix everything. We found enough light to keep going.

*(Sailing window: Western Caribbean — Perfect Day at CocoCay, Cozumel, Roatán | **March 2025**)*

## Intro
School ended **May 2024**. By that weekend I was on a **5-night** sailing, grading nothing but sunsets.

## The Crew and Staff
Edwin, my steward, saw the stack of essays and joked, “Permission granted to throw overboard.” I didn’t—but I did put myself at the top of the rubric.

## Embarkation & Disembarkation
Textbook logistics. Ten out of ten. Would recommend to principals everywhere.

## The Real Talk
Pool gets lively, Wi-Fi naps—but the [Solarium](/restaurants/solarium-bistro.html) hums like a library with better lighting.

## Tear-Jerker
A teen asked if I was a teacher. When I said yes, she hugged me and said, “Thank you for trying.” I cried behind my sunglasses.

## Closing Thoughts
I returned with lesson plans and a softer heart.

*(Sailing window: Western Caribbean — Cozumel, Costa Maya | **May 2024**)*

## Intro
We finally lined up schedules in **July 2024** and grabbed a **5-night** sailing—Perfect Day and Cozumel.

## The Crew and Staff
Our waiter sang happy birthday in three languages; the entertainment host taught us line-dances we absolutely did not master.

## Embarkation & Disembarkation
Fast on, slower off—because we were crying from laughing at inside jokes born on Deck 5.

## The Real Talk
Loungers go early; friendship doesn’t. The best seat was around our table.

## Tear-Jerker
A crew member snapped a candid of us mid-cackle. “You look like sisters,” she said. Two of us don’t have sisters. Now we do.

## Closing Thoughts
Some trips fade. This one etched laughter lines we plan to keep.

*(Sailing window: Western Caribbean — Perfect Day at CocoCay, Cozumel | **July 2024**)*

## Disclosure

## Intro
Our daughter uses a wheelchair; vacations can feel like obstacle courses. In **August 2024**, we tried a **7-night** Western Caribbean run—and found ramps instead of hurdles.

## The Crew and Staff
Guest services pre-arranged theater seating; lifeguards had the pool lift ready within minutes. Our steward mapped the smoothest routes to the Promenade.

## Embarkation & Disembarkation
From terminal curb to cabin door was shockingly simple. Disembarking, a crew member knelt to our daughter’s eye level and said, “Captain, report back next summer.” She saluted.

## The Real Talk
Elevators get busy, but patience plus planning wins. The ship’s smaller footprint actually helped.

## Tear-Jerker
Our daughter rang the ship’s bell at sailaway while the whole deck cheered. I pretended the wind made my eyes water.

## Closing Thoughts
We didn’t just vacation—we *belonged*.

*(Sailing window: Western Caribbean — Perfect Day at CocoCay, Cozumel, Roatán | **August 2024**)*

## Intro
Our crew of four booked **October 2024**, **5 nights**. We came for Promenade people-watching and Chops Grille ribeyes.

## The Crew and Staff
Chops remembered our doneness by night two; Latte-tudes knew our espresso order by night one. The maître d’ placed us where the promenade “just so” framed every meal.

## Embarkation & Disembarkation
Embark like you own the place, disembark like you’re leaving a favorite café—slowly.

## The Real Talk
You’ll find tighter elevators and classic fittings—not a mall at sea. That’s the point.

## Tear-Jerker
In Cozumel we toasted my mom’s remission with street tacos. Back onboard, our waiter quietly added a candle to dessert.

## Closing Thoughts
Adventure proves scale isn’t the same as soul.

*(Sailing window: Western Caribbean — Perfect Day at CocoCay, Cozumel | **October 2024**)*

## Disclosure
Full disclosure: I have not yet sailed Adventure of the Seas. Until I do, this Logbook is an aggregate of vetted guest soundings, taken in their own wake, trimmed and edited to our standards.

## Intro
Kids launched, house quiet. In **November 2024**, we celebrated 25 years on a **6-night** Western Caribbean sailing.

## The Crew and Staff
Housekeeping shaped our towels into swans; the maître d’ saved the same window table every night. We learned the rhythm of the Promenade musicians and made it ours.

## Embarkation & Disembarkation
We walked aboard holding hands like we did at 22. We walked off promising not to wait another decade.

## The Real Talk
Shows feel classic, not cutting-edge; Wi-Fi is more “postcard” than “Zoom.” Perfect.

## Tear-Jerker
At sailaway my husband pulled a wrinkled note from his wallet—his vows. He read the last line over the wake. I said yes again.

## Closing Thoughts
We came to celebrate time. The sea slowed it down just long enough to notice.

*(Sailing window: Western Caribbean — Perfect Day at CocoCay, Nassau, Cozumel | **November 2024**)*
